of fields of perception*
The alphabet itself, at least 2500 years ago, set up this fragmentation
of the field of attention, and automatically therefore released the
beginning of the process of pushing all except one thing at a time into
the subliminal area, so that as James Joyce puts it. literary cultures
are "Abced-minded , the puns absentmindecJ and ab-said minded are rel¬

It has to be In order to achieve the ends it sets itself of applied
knowledge, of breaking things up into bits so that it can master them
and hold them statically for analytic purposes - such a culture inevit¬
ably disintegrates itself systematically, organized disintegration of
perception is the very technique of such a culture, and such has been
the course pursued in the Western world for 2500 and more years. Now
in our own time, the past century at most, since the commercial use of
the telegraph in 1850, we have moved into an all-at-once world, in so
far as electronic means permit a simultaneous field of information to
exist, whether in the newspaper, or now on the TV image - and what is
so obvious about this revolution is that it is an all-at-once rather
than a one thing at a time field of perception which is offered for
human attention. This, as I have suggested many tines, many places,
is also to say that our western culture has shifted from a visual
analytic stress, to an auditory, synthetic integrating stress - for
the simple reason that an all-at-once field, mosaic of items, possesses
inevitably an auditory space character.
